Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: Around 2 hours on labs and 3 hours on group project per week towards end of semester.
2.5hrs
3-5 hours
5-10 hours

Sometimes I would spend 3-4 hours doing the HW lab only to get an extremely low grade from the TAs grading the HW. The HW needs to be based on effort, not on how correct the coding is. Most of the class will never use these programs again, so grading on correctness is useless.
10-15 hours on homework assignments

It was great, I learned a lot and really liked how there were multiple assignments (not just all weighted on an exam or final project). TF's were AMAZING and course content was very useful for the future. Would've liked to have it more focused on STATA (seems like more useful of a skill) than SAS.

This course gives you an overview of statistical methods used in healthcare and hands-on practice with these methods. While the content is helpful, the instruction is often bland. The format of this class should change from being lecture-based to lab-based and allowing you to practice the methods in a smaller, more focused environment. The large lecture hall setting doesn't work with presentation of such technical material.

The main material presented in this course - various statistical/econometric models and how to use them - is relevant and important. However, the professor did not teach the material in a way that was conducive to thorough learning.
Professor Chen's slides were very helpful for studying and his exams were fair. The labs were very useful and practical. The final group project is great for real world application.
Strengths were that the course taught important methods for analysis of data. Weaknesses are that it is a bit slow paced and we learn maybe 5 methods.

This was a very helpful class to learn SAS and diver deeper into how public health research is actually conducted. We discussed many interesting topics, however the course felt a bit disorganized at times.
Good course.
i loved the instructor, he obviously cared about his students, but the material itself was so methodical and dry, it was hard to keep the course interesting
good
this course was definitely not something I'm interested in long-term, but the professor did a good job of trying to make the material accessible to everyone.

Strengths: Timely feedback, good progression of material
Improvements: a couple of hours on a monday night is a bit long; would it be possible to consider splitting the class into 2 parts, and having it meet twice a week?

The quizzes provided in class were a joke. Sincerely, worst I've ever seen. It conveys nothing more than the laziness on the part of the professor and the TAs. They were replicas of the practice tests.

This was a great course. It provides a strong foundation in health services research for those who wish to explore this topic further and equips students who do not wish to pursue health services research to understand the evidence base to craft better informed policy recommendations. I had limited confidence in this topic area prior to taking this course, and while I do not anticipate I will pursue a career in research, I feel well equipped to understand this topic area. Specifically, I appreciated the logical progression of course topics which built on one another. In addition, the assessments made a lot of sense and I could see how they helped to build my skills in this area. The assessments were very reasonable and clearly measured mastery of the material. Lastly, each lecture contained a broad set of examples that illustrated how these concepts were applied, "in the real world," which was extremely helpful to understand the material, recognize these research practices, and better understand health services research overall. The only weakness of the course was the timing-- 5:00pm on a Monday meant that students were generally tired and paid less attention and attendance was usually pretty low.

Course was so well-designed!! Labs were graded every other week to give flexibility in getting them done.  Sufficient TFs and office-hours.  Quizzes were timed in a way that considered our mental health, and were a bit offset from other classes.  Final project allowed us to practice what we learned in a real way.  Satisfying course.
Pretty good
New course for me. Really learnt a lot.

Loved this class! Although this class has a pretty steep learning curve, I think it taught me a lot and gave me a lot of hard skills that I can apply elsewhere. Prior to this class, I was pretty uncomfortable with doing anything quantitative and I didn't really want to learn more about coding but after this class, I feel like I'm pretty comfortable with Stata and look forward to learning more in this realm. I think that this class does a good job at teaching us how to use our preferred coding language (whether it's SAS or Stata). I think this class was also great for teaching us the methods to determine causality that we will interact with a lot in the future, especially those of us pursuing PhDs or going into more research. Overall, great class! Only downside of the class was that it was set for 5-7 pm: I think this was too late just because the material can be slightly not exciting all the time so an earlier time would help a lot!
Great course for an introduction to SAS as well as reinforcement of data analysis and regression methods.
relevant course. I think it should be taught in stat or R instead since SAS is being phased out.

Strengths: Incredibly useful/relevant concepts

Weakness: Course content can be a little dry at times.

The material I have learned from the course is very useful. I am especially glad to have a lot some very basic causal inference methods such as IV, DID, RD.  While these methods were taught in an econometric context, I think they are applicable to other disciplines, including epidemiology. I enjoyed working on a group project, but I wish there were first draft and second draft deadlines for students to receive feedback from the instructors as opposed to getting most of them during the group presentations. There should also be a rubric for students to know what was expected of them. We just came in doing what we thought was appropriate and expected, but our assumptions aren't always correct. Nevertheless, exams were straightforward, and it is clear that the teaching team wanted students to do well! Overall, I had a positive experience in the course.

Please assign groups next time. My friends signed up to be in the same group and it was extremely stressful as one member decided to take a back seat because we were all his friends and did not contribute until the very end, putting more work on everyone else's plate who had already completed their portion weeks in advance. If we had not been friends, they would likely not have done that. And this happened in multiple groups.
I really enjoyed this course and I learned a lot. The Teaching Fellows seemed to contradict each other at times during labs, which was a little confusing.
Fantastic! Professor Chen was an incredibly encouraging and supportive professor and the TF team was always accessible for help.

Fantastic course!  Both the TFs and Professor Chen were phenomenal and extremely helpful.  Course expectations were clear and the course incorporated real world examples.

Weaknesses: none
very good, way better than the first semester biostats. this is the first time statistics has seemed relevant, I could see how this tools could be relevant for me in the future.
This is a really useful course. We learned so many tools that will be helpful in our future careers, and are better able to interpret studies we encounter in the literature.
Good course that ticks the boxes of gearing students up for more statistical work.
poorly scheduled - evening course, tough topic, why!
Lectures are tough. The room is totally wrong. It encourages people to not pay attention.  Need to get a smaller room to force students to engage.
Since we already took biostats, I think this class was redundant - lots of similar topics were covered.

strengths- relevant application of statistical methods to health problems
weaknesses - instructor read off the slides and did not provide much insight besides the course material
Good overview of issues - could be improved by focusing on newer statistical packages
Learned a lot in SAS but lectures were very confusing.

The class time wasn't optimal, and the material was presented in a dry way but I think stats in general is pretty dry. The labs were definitely helpful for understanding the content. I think the content presented in the course is very useful for the real-world and worth learning. It would be better to have more project-based assignemnts versus exams.
too many labs at the start, should be more spread about and more instruction time towards it (that's more flexible)
N/A
The course is a good intro to methods research, but the labs felt all over the place and weren't conducive to actually teaching students how to use statistical programs.

The way everything was graded was a mess. The tests were open notes, which makes them almost pointless and leads to most not actually learning anything.  The labs were graded harshly with few corrections, which also led to me not learning much.  Overall, it was pretty pointless for me to take this class and I didn't learn really anything new of note.

This was a very useful course for me. I've long wondered how data can best be used to establish not just causation, but causality. That was the crux of this course, and I was taught about the may different methods that one can use to establish this.

Strengths
- Material was relatively easy to understand
- Homework assignments were a great way to solidify concepts instead of frantically cramming our graded assignments into 1 session per week with a deliverable at the end of the session
- Lab sessions were a great opportunity to get help
- Very supportive and responsive TFs (able to schedule meetings and solve problems by email)
- Very supportive and responsive instructor (responded to questions by email, easily accessible office hours)
- Ability to create formula sheets and take them into quizzes. Allowed me to focus on understanding and not memorizing the material

Weaknesses
- Lectures/Instructor frequently not easy to understand (accent), compensated for by other components of the course structure (lab, TFs, office hours
Super helpful, kind and approachable. Less examples in class and slowing down would've been better. Wasn't too supportive on the final project,  but it worked out in the end anyway (hopefully).

Dr. Chen was very supportive but I often felt that he didn't understand our questions. When we went to see him for our group project, he neglected to mention that we should be making key transformations to our data prior to analysis. I would expect this kind of assistance to be provided during office hours/appointments with the professor.

Knows his material very well and can answer any question a student has. However, went into too much detail and lecture slides were simply too long. More explanation of the mechanics of models would be useful.

Xi is incredibly nice, helpful, and available for students.  He's very passionate and knowledgeable.

The class was purely lecture, however, with no attendance requirement, and therefore student engagement was VERY low.
Professor Chen is a great instructor. He is very kind, which creates a healthy learning environment to ask questions.

Professor Chen is so nice and helpful! He would bring candy to exams and for holidays which was really nice and refreshing. He also is very timely about getting back to people's questions. The environment created during lecture was very welcoming and all questions were taken and answered.
Professor Chen is extremely encouraging and very helpful. He clearly cares about his students and wants all of us to succeed.
He is open to questions and accessible to meet and discuss things for the final project.
he was great and easy to approach
good

Xi Chen is amazing! Just the sweetest man, who clearly cares about each and every one of his students. Very encouraging and truly believes each of us can do well. All three TFs for this course were truly outstanding and took their jobs seriously. I think Xi Chen sets a positive tone for them and coordinates the TFs well. His lecturing is very dry but his slides are well put together and easy to refer to later.
Tries to make sure everyone succeeds!
N/A

Professor Chen is a fantastic instructor and I am very thankful to have taken this course with him as the professor. He was very patient and understanding with students and often explained concepts in a variety of ways to make sure everyone understood. In addition, he made an effort to show us how concepts we learned in class were applied in "the real world" by explaining landmark and timely studies during lectures. This helped students to gain a better understanding of the material. Most importantly, Prof. Chen was extremely accessible and enthusiastic about student success. I really enjoyed having him as a professor and think other instructors could learn from his example.

Truly cares about his students understanding the material, and does a great job at answering questions and providing practical feedback.  He was so helpful in office hours!  Sometimes a bit hard to follow in a long lecture, but the design of the course made up for any of that.
Good
Very nice teacher. Willing to help.

Loved Xi Chen! Great professor and I think he explained concepts really well and his exams were incredibly fair which was nice! Wish he would continue teaching this class because it was great and he was amazing and very helpful!
Professor Chen is very approachable and obviously knowledgeable about the subject. I think he is great to teach this class.
Great. really passionate about his work and you can see it.
Professor Chen is so nice! It is evident that he truly wants students to do well. Very supportive, too.

Prof. Chen is very knowledgeable and kind. He's incredibly responsive to students and helpful in office hours, especially if one needs help with the group project. It is clear that he wants students to do well in the course!
Xi was an amazing professor that really encouraged and supported his students to understand the importance of statistics in health policy.
Professor Chen is an excellent instructor. He always made sure that students were comfortable with a topic before moving on to other topics.

Professor Chen was a great professor! He was always available to discuss class topics and concerns. He was able to provide useful feedback regularly. His lectures were not the most exciting, but he made challenging material very straightforward.
Nice! Provided timely feedback, clear powerpoint slides, and relevant course examples.  Super willing to meet to go over final project!
I appreciate his enthusiasm. i really like the way he always provided relevant examples.
So nice and encouraging!
Professor Chen was wonderful and presented course material in a way that was very intuitive, making difficult concepts easy to understand.
Difficult to answer in a lecture capacity, but perhaps could've been somewhat more engaging at times. His content was outstanding, and he consistently tied it to real-world/academic issues
Very caring and clear professor in a one on one situation but a poor lecturer.
Professor Chen is knowledgeable and kind. He'd benefit from instituting a no laptop policy.
Professor Chen is very energetic and always willing to make time to meet with students.
could have communicated more clearly and succintly
Very supportive professor and passionate about topic.
Really nice and willing to help out!
Professor Chen is so knowledgable and kind. He really cares about his students and the class. Great professor!
Very supportive and intelligent professor, lucky to have him in the department
Really such a kind and compassionate professor. Very appreciative of his passion for students and the subject matter.

Professor Chen is so kind and such an expert. He was so helpful with the final projects and very willing to meet with students. I do wish he could find a way to make his lectures more engaging, they were often a bit dry. Also the 5-7pm time slot is brutal.

I can barely understand him and he goes so fast, before asking if everyone understands. The way he organized the class was terrible, where we often had no idea when things were due and where to submit them.  He seems like a really nice guy honestly, but I don't think he's a very good teacher.

Our professor was very nice, and extremely helpful. He's tremendously knowledgable, and he was always available to provide insight. He was also always very willing to provide a different way of explaining concepts, on the spot, during lectures.

Outstanding overall. Very supportive.
Innovative course design that was focused on building knowledge instead of on cramming and memorizing theory and programming code
Great! Would recommend to anyone who wants to understand research (data-focused especially) in a new light.

This was a required course, I wouldn't have taken it otherwise. Skip lecture and review the notes yourself. Go to lab if you're really struggling with homework, otherwise that can be completed on your own.
If you are interested in learning how to code various statistical models, and are VERY self-motivated and willing to go above and beyond, this class can be helpful.
Straightforward course, weekly lab assignments w/2 "quizzes" and a final project.  The labs do take a considerable amount of time to do them well if you have limited experience in SAS/STATA.
Helpful if you want to put what you've learned in Biostats to use.
I would recommend. It's a really useful course and it's not extremely demanding. The professor and TA are really helpful too!
Good course. Information was not so relevant for Health Care Management students.
not sure if this is relevant in my career
good

I really would recommend taking this if you want to write a thesis and need a basic understanding of research methods. I know SAS about 100x better than I know R despite having like half as many labs in methods than we had in biostats.
Entirely overlaps with other courses - take something else.

This course provides a foundation level of understanding in health services research and econometrics that lays a foundation for future careers in academia and equips thought leaders to make better-informed decisions based on the available evidence. 

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student.
Well-designed course if you want an intro to SAS in a challenging but do-able way.  Provides a good frame to feel capable of doing a thesis next year.
good
Learning about health economics. Fun experience.

This is a class that teaches you the basics for coding econometrics method designs while teaching you when and why to use certain models. I would definitely recommend this class to another student, especially if they want to learn more about modeling!
Great class to reinforce regression and data analysis skills; really nice opportunity to work on a group project with other students.
I would recommend it. I felt that I learned relevant information that would help me in the future.
Relevant content - course is worthwhile.

Very useful and not so difficult. Earlier assignments might be a bit challenging for someone who does not have more intensive training in SAS, but it's definitely manageable to pick up the codes in a few weeks! The material is applied and assignments are meant to give you practical skills.
It's a great introduction to health econometrics and SAS if you haven't had experience in them before.

I learned a lot in this course and would highly recommend it to a student. I would also recommend taking anything that Professor Chen teaches. He is a great professor and I hope to be able to take more classes with him next year!
I would recommend this course to all YSPH students.

One of the best courses I have ever taken!

Definitely provided knowledge to assist in future research in health services.  

The professor and TFs were incredibly helpful and the quizzes were fair.  Final project was a lot of work but interesting and applicable.
interesting about the application of statistices
Yes, useful skills!
tough, but can't get out of it.
Mandatory requirement. Get through it.
Overall, I would not have taken this class if it weren't required. The main concepts are covered in biostats/other stats classes.
its a course that reteaches concepts from biostats and requires completion of a sas/stata problem set weekly where you do most of the learning
Definitely take it to learn the content.
Take it your first year
Very hands on and applicable
Yes for health policy if you want to understand how to do the simplest health research.
Well it is a required class, but I wouldn't recommend it for others to take. I took nothing from this class except less appreciation for statistics.

This was a relatively standard course, as far as workload goes. I learned a tremendous amount about the various methods one could use to establish trends and causality using datasets. For my concentration (health policy), I knew that this would be an essential skill to learn, and I'm very glad I took this course.

Great learning experience. Requirements are reasonable. 
Would recommend attending lab sessions and meeting with TFs in order to progress with Homework assignments.
More difficult to figure out some questions solo without these resources.
Assignments are a great way to solidify concepts.
Excellent course
